page.lettertext:
fol.201r
Belgia
May it please yo
r
good L. sins
e writing [of]
my last
e 2 of this moneth, upon occasion [of]
some talke I shewed
M
r
Buzenval
, that th[.]
the
states
should denie, to send more forces of [their]
owne for
e service of
e
Kinge,
yet they cow[ld not]
well refuse, upon her
Ma
ties
request, to send [a]
thousand Englishe, of those
at are appointed [in]
e service of
e feelde. For aswell her Ma
tie
[.]
might take of her owne subjectes in these countr[ies]
and imploye them in
France,
w
t
out
e licence [of]
the states, as
Holland
alone had already [.]
some bandes, of their owne repartition, w
t
ou[t]
asking
e consent of
e rest of
e union. And
when
e Englishe are away, they might happ[ely]
be wonne, to spare as many of their owne: [.]
that I thought they would doe litle, w
t
out t[he]
assistance of o
r
nation. To this he
answeared, That by way of discourse, not [.]
passing a moneth before, he had used speech[e to]
Count Maurice
, to
e very like effect. An[d]
at
e Count made him answear, That he w[as]
wholy of opinion, if her Ma
tie
would be [.]
for her owne people onely, that
e states [.]
not use any great contradiction. But [.]
thinke therupon,
at when
e Englishe w[.]
parted, they would doe nothing of the[.]
to
e annoiance of
e Enemie, it was [but]
an abuse. For said he, I remember [.]
upon an other like occasion, I told M[.]
in
e open Councel, That although
e E[nglishe]
forces were drawen away from hens, [.]
Messieurs les Estats ne laisseront s[.]
faire la guerre.
This was
e [.]
of M
r
Buzenval unto me. Whereunto [.]
fol.201v
That undoubtedly
e Count was greatly mis-
taken. For I never heard him utter any
suche kinde of speeche, nether privatly nor pub
lickly: and
at he might be well assured, if
any suche mater had bin spoken in my presence
he should not have caried it so cleanely away
I must have pressed him to knowe, whether
at
whiche he delivered were his privat opinion, or
e
general conceat of
e states of
e contrey. For
I was sure it would prove very welcome newes
unto her Ma
tie
. That they were able of themselves
w
t
out her Hig
nes
assistance, to maintene there
owne estate. But howsoever
e Count might
have uttered this to him, I did not thinke that
e states would cunne him any thankes, for any
suche discourse. And as for me I requested,
at
he would certifie
e Count, as much as I had
saied: w
ch
he promised he would. The
next day after he came unto me, and signified,
that having told
e Count, what talke I had
w
t
him, he could not well remember, whether [it]
was to me, or to some other of
e Councel, that he
had cast out suche a worde: but he did not
deme it, and yet he said it was but spoken in
a sleight kinde of sort, and upon an incident
occasion, and
at he would not in no wise in-
teresse
e state in any suche assertion. Wher-
upon M
r
Buzenval was urgent upon me, to
lette it passe away in silence. Howbeit for
at other point, astouching
e states willingnes, to
permitte
e Englishe troupes, w
ch
are heere to be
imploied in
e service of
e feelde, to be called
into France,
e Count did not doubt, but ra[ther]
did assure him,
at after
e perfourmance o[f]
fol.202r
enterprise on
Steenwicke,
they would be ea-
sely intreated to lette them goe. This I
thought expedient to make knowen to yo
r
L.
And yet because M
r
Buzenval hath bin instant
w
t
me, not to take any notice of
at w
ch
e Count
had uttered in Councel, aswel for
at I was so
desired, as to
e end it should not cause an over
strangenesse between us, w
ch
might also be a lette,
to
e compassing of suche suites, as shall require
or joint endevo
rs
, I could wishe it would stand
w
t
yo
r
L. good pleasure, not to lette
it
to
appeere
at
any suche mater is come to yo
r
knowledge.
But yet to deliver my privat opinion of
e speeche
of
e Count, because he longeth exceedingly to
make himself great, and to be voide of controlle-
ment, w
ch
is plaine enough to see by
e course of
all his actions; and for
at
e interest of her Hig
nes
in
e gouvernment of this state, by reason of
e
Contract, may alwaies be a bridle, to restraine
him of his purposes, I doe therfor thinke for
certaine,
at he wisheth w
t
his hart,
at there were
no Englishe in
e contrey: Upon
e hope of suche
a time, and because his state will hardly stande
w
t
out
e special protection of some neighbo
r
poten-
tat, he doth greatly make love to all
e Frenche
nation, and so doe all
at are about him of his
frindes and folowers: w
ch
is continually inter-
tened by
e
Princesse of Orenge
, by M
r
Buzenval
and others, and chiefly by
e Kinge, by his often
writing to
e state, and to
e Count, w
t
dilig
e
t
advertisments of all his actions and deseignes,
w
ch
M
r
Buzenval procureth to be speedely sent
hither: whome
e Kinge hath also lately, by his spe-
cial l
re
s to
e state, appointed his Ambassado
r
fol.202v
to reside in these contreis. Supposing [.]
yo
r
L. would be willing to be informed [of]
suche cariage of maters heere, I doe signi[fie]
at unto yo
w
, w
ch
I have every day occa[sioned]
to observe more and more. I [have]
sent yor L. heerinclosed
e answear of [the]
Count to her Ma
ties
last letter, w
t
w
ch
he al[so]
sendeth certaine l
re
s to my
L. of Essex
, an[d]
S
r
John Norreis
. But there is no deali[ng]
w
t
e states for any answear to
at mate[r]
till
ei heare howe
e King hath spedde ag[ainst]
Parma
: w
ch
is expecte every houre, and [.]
upon
e intelligence will addresse my self [.]
unto them, for a present resolution.
An[d]
so I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hag[e]
May 5 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bouden Tho. Bod[ley]
